headline.main: How Google Could Keep Yahoo From Microsoft

docs.abstract: Google could help keep Yahoo away from Microsoft if it took over selling search ads for Yahoo in return for a very large check. That money could help finance all sorts of possible deals. But taking search out of Yahoo could well destroy a lot of the value in the company.

docs.snippet: The weekend was rife with media speculation about Microsoft's Yahoo bid and how it could play out. The San Francisco Chronicle wondered about the fates of "dozens" of overlapping Internet services at the two Web giants, and Reuters suggested that ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The weekend was rife with media speculation about Microsoft's Yahoo bid and how it could play out. The San Francisco Chronicle wondered about the fates of "dozens" of overlapping Internet services at the two Web giants, and Reuters suggested that a combined Microsoft and Yahoo would be a "Noah's Ark of a Web company" -- one with two of everything. Vindu Goel, writing in the San Jose Mercury News, suggested that integration could be such a distraction that it works in favor of archrival Google.

docs.snippet: America Movil, the wireless operator, said that it would feature YouTube.com videos on its cellphones in a drive to increase customers. An America Movil spokeswoman said YouTube videos would be first available on all 3G equipment — the latest ta...
docs.lead_paragraph: America Movil, the wireless operator, said that it would feature YouTube.com videos on its cellphones in a drive to increase customers. An America Movil spokeswoman said YouTube videos would be first available on all 3G equipment — the latest take on wireless communications — in Mexico but that they would extend to company operations in other parts of Latin America. Diego Molina, head of business development for Google in Latin America, said YouTube would be available to customers in Brazil by the end of April. YouTube has local sites in over 15 countries, including Mexico and Brazil. As part of YouTube’s two-year deal with America Movil, the video Web site plans to share advertising revenue with the Mexican company.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the 18 months or so that I've been covering Yahoo and its competitors here, I've run into a good number of dejected, demoralized Yahoo employees. I've also run into many who have mixed feelings -- they love Yahoo, but think it was mismanaged -- and many others who can't say enough good things about the place. That includes many people who chose to leave -- not because of ill will toward Yahoo but because their careers took them elsewhere.

docs.snippet: It's not exactly light reading, but there's plenty of good news in a report from the National Academy of Engineering. It's a list of the "Grand Challenges" in engineering this century compiled by an array of experts like the genetics researcher J....
docs.lead_paragraph: It's not exactly light reading, but there's plenty of good news in a report from the National Academy of Engineering. It's a list of the "Grand Challenges" in engineering this century compiled by an array of experts like the genetics researcher J. Craig Ventner and Google's Larry Page. What's encouraging isn't so much the list itself (which has predictably virtuous endeavors like improving the urban infrastructure) but the big picture if offers by comparing past achievements with the challenges of today.

docs.lead_paragraph: UPDATE: Two Google officials, Matt Cutts, a top search engineer, and Peter Fleischer, Google's global privacy counsel, wrote comments below reacting to this post. I wrote some thoughts responding to their comments in another post here.

headline.main: Google Says I.P. Addresses Aren't Personal

docs.abstract: Responding to regulators in Europe, Google argues that the Internet Protocol address associated with a computer shouldn't be protected as personal information. But I.P. addresses can be used, along with other information, to track what people do online.

headline.main: HLTH's WebMD Merger Creates Attractive Deal Target

docs.abstract: The merger of HLTH Corporation and WebMD Health could make the combined company a takeover target for larger Internet companies such as Google, industry observers said Thursday. HLTH announced Thursday that it would merge into its 84-percent-owned subsidiary, WebMD, in a $2.3 billion deal. Under terms of the transaction, each outstanding share of HLTH common [...]

headline.main: Google Shoots for the Moon

docs.abstract: More than three decades after the last Apollo astronauts roamed the lunar surface, disparate universities, open-source engineers and quixotic aerospace start-ups are planning to start their own robotic missions to the Earth's barren cousin. The return to the moon is part of the Google Lunar X Prize, a competition sponsored by Google with $30 million [...]

docs.snippet: Ten teams from five countries plan to compete for $30 million in prizes in the Google-sponsored race to the moon....
docs.lead_paragraph: Ten teams from five countries plan to compete for $30 million in prizes in the Google-sponsored race to the moon.

headline.main: A Google Competition, With a Robotic Moon Landing as a Goal
headline.print_headline: A Google Competition, With a Robotic Moon Landing as a Goal

docs.snippet: Google responded to a Bits post that challenged its view that Internet Protocol addresses are not personal information. But even Google agrees that I.P. addresses, when combined with other information, can often identify a person or at least a hou...
docs.lead_paragraph: My post about whether Google's records of the Internet Protocol address should be considered personal information under privacy law, brought two comments from Googlers: Matt Cutts, an engineer, and from Peter Fleischer, Google's global privacy counsel.

headline.main: I.P. Address: Partially Personal Information

docs.abstract: Google responded to a Bits post that challenged its view that Internet Protocol addresses are not personal information. But even Google agrees that I.P. addresses, when combined with other information, can often identify a person or at least a household.

docs.snippet: Google joins a telecom group to build a trans-Pacific undersea cable to reduce its high costs of sending search, video and applications traffic around the world....
docs.lead_paragraph: Google said Monday that it was part of a six-company consortium that would build a new $300 million high-capacity underwater fiber-optic cable linking the United States and Japan.

headline.main: Google and the Undersea Cable

docs.abstract: Google joins a telecom group to build a trans-Pacific undersea cable to reduce its high costs of sending search, video and applications traffic around the world.

docs.lead_paragraph: Having exhausted its best ideas on how to deal with Google, Microsoft is now working its way down the list to dubious ones - like pursuing a hostile bid for Yahoo, says Randall Stross, writing in The New York Times.

headline.main: Maybe Microsoft Should Stalk Different Prey

docs.abstract: Having exhausted its best ideas on how to deal with Google, Microsoft is now working its way down the list to dubious ones – like pursuing a hostile bid for Yahoo, says Randall Stross, writing in The New York Times. If Microsoft thinks this is the right time to try a major acquisition on a [...]

docs.snippet: Google's Software Too Cheap?     When Google bought Postini last year for $625 million, it was making a big commitment to the enterprise software business. Not surprisingly, Google is not committing itself to business as usual. And it is causing a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google's Software Too Cheap? When Google bought Postini last year for $625 million, it was making a big commitment to the enterprise software business. Not surprisingly, Google is not committing itself to business as usual. And it is causing a little heat among Postini's existing partners.

headline.main: Google's Software Too Cheap?

docs.abstract: Bits column notes Google's slashing of software prices by up to 90 percent is adversely affecting companies that sell systems by its Postini division, which it bought in 2007 (S)

docs.snippet: Randy Falco, the chief executive of AOL, told a group of advertising executives that Microsoft is making a mistake in going after Yahoo. Unlike Google, which is trying to block the deal, he's not going to get in the way....
docs.lead_paragraph: Nobody could get off the stage at the Interactive Advertising Bureau convention here in Phoenix without being asked about the prospect of Microsoft's acquisition of Yahoo.

headline.main: Randy Falco's Napoleonic Strategy at AOL

docs.abstract: Randy Falco, the chief executive of AOL, told a group of advertising executives that Microsoft is making a mistake in going after Yahoo. Unlike Google, which is trying to block the deal, he's not going to get in the way.

docs.snippet: Pakistan drops its YouTube blockade, and Google invest in undersea cables....
docs.lead_paragraph: News agencies are reporting that the Pakistani government lifted its restrictions on its citizens' access to YouTube after a video that it deemed blasphemous was removed. And the nation confirmed that its decision to impose those restrictions accidentally led to a global disruption of YouTube for two hours on Sunday.

headline.main: YouTube Returns to Pakistan: Calm on the Internet, for Now

docs.abstract: Pakistan drops its YouTube blockade, and Google invest in undersea cables.

docs.snippet: Yahoo is starting to reveal tidbits of its ambitious advertising system. It appears to be taking the merger of Google and DoubleClick head on in both technology and the use of data about users....
docs.lead_paragraph: The meat of the presentation by Jerry Yang, chief executive, and Sue Decker, president, of Yahoo at the Interactive Advertising Bureau's convention Monday was a new advertising system called Apex (for Advertiser Publisher Exchange).

headline.main: Yahoo Reveals (Some) Details About Its Ad Plans

docs.abstract: Yahoo is starting to reveal tidbits of its ambitious advertising system. It appears to be taking the merger of Google and DoubleClick head on in both technology and the use of data about users.

The start-up also announced that it's opening its doors to the public in a beta launch. Go to [...]

headline.main: Google Goes After Another Microsoft Cash Cow

docs.abstract: Google broadens its assault on Microsoft's business software franchise with a program that allows groups of workers to jointly create Web documents.

docs.snippet: Investors were spooked by a report by the research firm comScore that said clicks on Google ads in the United States were flat in January....
docs.lead_paragraph: Investors were spooked by a report by the research firm comScore that said clicks on Google ads in the United States were flat in January.

headline.main: A Highflier Loses Altitude as Google’s Clicks Go Flat
headline.print_headline: A Highflier Loses Altitude As Google’s Clicks Go Flat

docs.snippet: Some search marketers report that Google's growth is not slowing down after all....
docs.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, a report by comScore said that Internet users in the United States were clicking on Google ads far less frequently than expected. The news spooked investors, fanning worries that Google's growth might be stalling, and that the company would not be immune to the broader economic slowdown. The company's shares, which have been falling since their early November peak, dropped 4.6 percent on Tuesday. They regained some ground in the last two days.

headline.main: Data Points on Google's Growth

docs.abstract: Some search marketers report that Google's growth is not slowing down after all.

headline.main: Digg's Rose Tamps Down Deal Speculation

docs.abstract: If you believe the blog rumors, Kevin rose, the founder of Digg, a news site where readers rank stories, is constantly dealing with perpetual acquisition offers from companies such as Google and News Corporation. Indeed, Digg has apparently been so inundated with questions regarding a potential deal that the start-up's chief executive, Jay Adelson, recently [...]
